caseTitle: LT. COL. S. B. ASHUN v ACCRA BREWERY LTD.
summary: In LT. Col. S. B. Ashun v Accra Brewery Ltd., the Supreme Court of Ghana held that the plaintiff's acceptance of a severance package after being declared redundant extinguished his right to further legal claims, absent an express reservation of rights. The court rejected the argument that there was a legal duty to negotiate severance pay under the Labour (Amendment) Decree 1969, NLCD 342, clarifying that its provisions on negotiation apply only to organizational closures or amalgamations, not redundancy. It emphasized that a contract of employment is not a guarantee of lifelong employment and that damages for wrongful termination are limited to a reasonable period for securing new employment, subject to the duty to mitigate. The appeal was dismissed, affirming that the termination was not wrongful due to the mutual agreement implied by acceptance of the package.
citations: Nartey-Tokoli v Volta Aluminium Company [1987-88] 2 GLR 532
Ghana Cocoa Marketing Board v Agbettor & Ors [1984-86] 1 GLR 122
rationaleHighlights: A contract of employment does not guarantee employment until retirement age.
Damages for wrongful termination are limited to a reasonable period for finding alternative employment, subject to duty to mitigate.
Acceptance of severance package constitutes a compromise agreement, extinguishing further claims unless accepted under protest.
Paragraphs 34 and 35 of NLCD 342 do not apply to redundancy but to organizational closure or amalgamation.
No statutory duty to negotiate severance in redundancy cases absent specific contractual or statutory provisions.
